unnormalised: AIIMS Delhi is facing a bit of a "headache," literally! Apparently, there's been a sudden influx of patients complaining about phantom limb pain...in their brains! Dr. Rajesh Kumar, HoD of Neurology, jokingly said, "We're seeing cases where patients swear they can feel their left frontal lobe itching, even though it's, well, still there."
normalised: A-I-I-M-S Delhi is facing a bit of a "headache," literally! Apparently, there's been a sudden influx of patients complaining about phantom limb pain...in their brains! Doctor Rajesh Kumar, H-o-D of Neurology, jokingly said, "We're seeing cases where patients swear they can feel their left frontal lobe itching, even though it's, well, still there."

unnormalised: One patient, Mr. Sharma, even demanded a "brain massage" for his supposed discomfort. The hospital staff is now bracing themselves for a potential wave of people claiming they need "brain Botox" to smooth out those imaginary wrinkles. Consultations are up by 30% since last week, and the waiting list for neurological exams is longer than a Bollywood movie!
normalised: One patient, Mister Sharma, even demanded a "brain massage" for his supposed discomfort. The hospital staff is now bracing themselves for a potential wave of people claiming they need "brain Botox" to smooth out those imaginary wrinkles. Consultations are up by thirty percent since last week, and the waiting list for neurological exams is longer than a Bollywood movie!

unnormalised: But seriously folks, AIIMS Delhi is currently conducting extensive research to understand this unusual phenomenon. Initial assessments suggest a possible link to increased stress levels and overuse of social media. You know, spending too much time doomscrolling might just be messing with your grey matter. So, put down your phone, step away from the Twitterverse, and give your brain a break before you start feeling phantom TikTok notifications.

Initial assessments suggest a possible link to increased stress levels and overuse of social media. You know, spending too much time doomscrolling might just be messing with your grey matter. So, put down your phone, step away from the Twitterverse, and give your brain a break before you start feeling phantom TikTok notifications.

unnormalised: In the meantime, Dr. Kumar advises everyone to maintain a healthy lifestyle, practice meditation, and avoid reading too much medical jargon online. And if you do start feeling an inexplicable urge to scratch your parietal lobe, maybe just have a cup of chai and watch some brain-dead (pun intended) reality TV. It's cheaper than a neurologist's bill, that's for sure!
